content: The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" expands the definition of homeless veterans for benefits under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. It also establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans receiving the most healthcare from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" establishes a program for intensive case management interventions for homeless veterans enrolled in the Department's homeless registry and annual patient enrollment system. The program will be carried out at a minimum of six locations selected by the Secretary. The program under the "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" will be implemented at a minimum of six locations chosen by the Secretary, including cities with high homeless veteran populations and suburban or rural settings. The locations will have strong coordination between the Department and community organizations providing housing and services for veterans. Intensive case management interventions will be provided as part of the program. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" program will offer services like outreach, employment, and financial assistance for homeless, at-risk, and low-income veterans. Intensive case management interventions will be provided to a minimum of 20 covered veterans at each selected location to help them access housing and services they are entitled to under the laws administered by the Secretary. The "Veteran Housing Stability Act of 2015" program aims to assist covered veterans in gaining and maintaining access to housing and services, including benefits and services they are entitled to under the laws administered by the Secretary. A clerical amendment is also included in the legislation. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will start the intensive case management program by September 1, 2016. A report on the program's assessments, including types of interventions and housing status of veterans, must be submitted by December 1, 2018 to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The assessment of the intensive case management program shall include types of interventions, housing status, employment status before and after intervention, use of health care services, and costs incurred by veterans. The assessment of the intensive case management program includes the use and costs of health care services by veterans before and after receiving interventions, as well as the number of veterans who received these interventions. The assessment of the intensive case management program includes costs incurred by the Department for providing interventions in specific locations and estimates of healthcare costs for covered veterans. PROGRAM TO IMPROVE RETENTION OF HOUSING BY FORMERLY HOMELESS VETERANS AND VETERANS AT RISK OF BECOMING HOMELESS. The Secretary is required to carry out a program to improve housing retention for formerly homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness through case management services and grants. The Secretary will award grants to organizations prioritizing those with experience in providing case management services and transitional housing for homeless veterans. Extra priority will be given to organizations that voluntarily stop receiving funding and convert their facilities. The Secretary will prioritize organizations with experience in case management and transitional housing for homeless veterans. Extra priority will be given to organizations that voluntarily stop receiving funding and convert their facilities to provide permanent housing meeting housing quality standards. The person who received a grant for construction, rehabilitation, or acquisition under section 2011 of this title, and converts it as described, will not be considered in non-compliance with the grant terms. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will prescribe regulations for a program aimed at improving housing retention for homeless veterans. A report on the program's assessments must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs by June 1, 2019. The report on the program must include assessments of the percentage of veterans who retained permanent housing and those who did not, along with reasons for failing to retain housing. The report on the program must include assessments of veterans' retention of permanent housing, disaggregated by housing status and reasons for failure, as well as the use of housing assistance by veterans before and after receiving case management services. Additionally, it should assess the employment status of veterans before and after receiving case management services. Section 2012 of title 38, United States Code is amended to include a new subsection (e) requiring the Secretary to annually review grant recipients and eligible entities that received per diem payments to evaluate their performance in assisting veterans with housing and increasing their income. The Secretary must annually review grant recipients and eligible entities to evaluate their performance in assisting veterans with housing and increasing their income. Performance is measured by success in helping veterans obtain and retain housing, as well as increasing their income through employment or benefits.
